review.title: Robust Optimization for Tree-Structured Stochastic Network Design
review.abstract: Stochastic network design is a general framework for optimizing network connectivity. It has several applications in computational sustainability including spatial conservation planning, pre-disaster network preparation, and river network optimization. A common assumption in previous work has been made that network parameters (e.g., probability of species colonization) are precisely known, which is unrealistic in real- world settings. We therefore address the robust river network design problem where the goal is to optimize river connectivity for fish movement by removing barriers. We assume that fish passability probabilities are known only imprecisely, but are within some interval bounds. We then develop a planning approach that computes the policies with either high robust ratio or low regret. Empirically, our approach scales well to large river networks. We also provide insights into the solutions generated by our robust approach, which has significantly higher robust ratio than the baseline solution with mean parameter estimates.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 2 River Network Design
sections.text: The problem is defined as a directed, rooted tree T = (V, E) with a unique root denoted by s = 0. The edge v represents a contiguous region of the river network (e.g. the total length of all segments). An edge e encodes a river barrier under which every person can move freely without crossing any barriers. A node v is associated with a reward that is proportional to the total probability of the habitat in that region (e.g. the total length of all segments). Figure 1 shows how a river network is to be coded as a directed tree. Each barrier is associated with an overall probability that a fish can pass the barrier.

sections.heading: 3 Our Method
sections.text: We develop an iterative method (algorithm 1) to solve problem (2) using constraint generation (Boutilier et al. 2003). The overarching idea is to combine two optimization problems. First, the decision maker finds the best decision policy πT in relation to a limited opponent, who can only select policy parameter pairs from the finite group C. Then the opponent selects a new policy parameter pair in order to minimize the robust relationship with the current decision policy πT. The value of the decision maker U is an upper limit of the MRR value, since the opponent is limited to a finite subset of policy parameter pairs. The optimal value L of the opponent is a lower limit of the MRR value. At U = L we have an MRR-optimal decision policy. By allowing a small gap between the two boundaries, we can find a group R policy with almost optimal probabilities.

sections.heading: 3.1 The Decision Optimization Problem
sections.text: The goal of problem (3) is to find a decision-making policy that maximizes the robust relationship with the limited adversary. Figure 3 represents a mixed-integer linear program (MILP) to solve this problem, based on techniques from (Neeson et al. 2015). Variable M encodes the MRR value. Internal minimization is achieved by limiting inequality (6) to M. The continuous variable zp encodes the objective value of decision-making policy for determining probability p by (7). z (π; p) is a constant for each pair of measure parameters (π; p). C. xie is a binary decision variable that indicates whether the action i-Ae is applied to e (= 1) or not (= 0). Restriction (8) forces one and only one action to be taken on each edge, and (9) is the budgetary constraint that no action is taken on each edge.

sections.heading: 4 Other Criterion of Robustness
sections.text: A slightly different method of quantifying ruggedness is the use of regret (Kumar et al. 2016; Boutilier et al. 2003). The policy that minimizes regret is defined by the following measures: c (π) ≤ B max π ": c (π) ≤ B z (p) − z (π; p) (30) The robust ratio and regret correlate asz (π; p) z (π; p) = 1 − z (π; p) − z (π; p) z (p) z (π; p) z (p) z (π; p). The robust ratio is in some ways the scaled version of regret. In experiments, we show that the πMRR also evokes little regret compared to measures calculated using other basic methods. Our algorithm with minor changes can empirically find a near-optimal πMR.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: We use data from the CAPS project (McGarigal et al. 2011) for the river networks in Massachusetts and synthetically define the missing parameters from the data. The data provide the point estimates of the initial feasibility probabilities. We use the method in (Kumar et al. 2016) to define the intervals of the initial passage probabilities before taking action. The interval of an initial passage probability is [p − βp, p + βp], where p is a point estimate and β is a parameter that controls the interval probabilities: cultivations and dams. The point estimates for cultivations provided by the data are mostly in the range [0.8, 0.9]. A typical action that increases their passage probability to 1.0 and costs $100,000. Most of the point estimates for dams are less than 0.2. A typical action to repair a dam costs $3,030 and shifts its probability.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: The algorithm iteratively solves two optimization problems: the problem of decision optimization and the problem of quota minimization. The former is encoded in a MILP, and for the latter an FPTAS is developed, which is the more difficult problem. Empirically, we show that the strategies calculated by maximizing the robust ratio are more robust than strategies calculated by two other basic methods. In addition to searching for strategies with a high robust ratio, our algorithm can also produce strategies with little regret in large networks. These algorithms provide new calculation tools for environmental scientists who tackle decision problems with inaccurate models.
